titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V:30. Saturday.

The weather was so cold that I could not write in my chamber and yet I would postpone the making of a fire there— I made it and wrote in the dining room— Finished the revisal of the manuscript of the Eulogy for publication, and sent it to Mr Eastburn, by my Son Charles, who went to Boston, and returned to dine Mrs. and Miss Eliza S. Quincy were here in the forenoon, and Mr Hallett with a young man named Smith in the afternoon. Mr Smith’s object was to invite me to deliver an introductory Lecture to the Hanover Lyceum in Boston.— I had already declined two such invitations at Boston, and one at Charlestown. I declined again though very much pressed by Mr Smith, who said they did not wish me to take the trouble of writing, but to extemporize a discourse upon any subject I should choose I told him I was altogether unqualified for that; and I should certainly not undertake it with impunity— Mrs T. B. Adams, her daughter Elizabeth and her Son Isaac H, and Louisa C. Smith were here at tea; and Mrs Adams and Miss Smith spent the evening here. Charles and his wife, Mary, Elizabeth and Isaac H—went in to Mr Beale’s, and spent the Evening there— My garden, nursery and seminary have lost their charms but now commences the Season for sowing Seeds, and transplanting seedling trees. This morning I planted the third row, fronting the Nursery fence and East of the gate— A row of Dexter Apple-seeds—with four Shagbark nuts in the drupe 3 peach and 3 plum stones, and a medley of whole Pears, Cores and Seeds.
2. V:45. Sunday.

Communion day— Mr Lunt preached in the morning from Acts 2.23. “Him being delivered by the determinate counsel and foreknowledge of God ye have taken, and by wicked hands have crucified and slain.” A Sermon upon the crucifixion— The communion was administered partly by Mr Lunt and partly by Mr Whitney— After the hymn was sung, Mr Whitney announced that a collection would be taken up, for the annual expenses of the communion service; of which he had given notice on the last communion day. Captn John Souther then rose in his pew, and addressed him— “Reverend Sir.”— Can you inform me what use is to be made of the surplus of the collection if there should be any— Mr Whitney answered indirectly, that he should suppose it ought to be applied by a general vote of the Society— Mr Souther said enquiries upon this subject had
been made by numbers of persons, and that the amount of the collection would depend upon the answer— Mr Whitney said he did not know; repeated his opinion that the surplus ought to be disposed of by a vote of the congregation; and added that every one would give what he pleased— The collection was then taken up. Mr Lunt’s afternoon Sermon was from 1. Corinthians 11. and the verse I do not recollect; but the verse I do not recollect— It was however upon the character of St. Paul, and a sequel to a preceding Sermon upon his conversion— On returning home I found Mr Degrand, with Mr Clapp the Editor of the Boston Evening Gazette, and his Son at our house— They took tea with us, and returned to Boston in the Evening. Mr E. Price Greenleaf called late in the Evening with a note from Elizabeth C. Adams to my wife— I read the third Sermon of the 9th. Volume of Saurin, being the second on the examples of the Saints, and the third on perseverance— This part which is the conclusion of the whole Treatise was to me far more impressive than either of the former parts. The enumeration of the sins which most easily beset the youth, the manhood, and the old age of men, with the addition of those which bear upon all ages were full of instruction, if I were capable of receiving it. “Avec la vielless arrivent les infirmités, les chagrins, les soucis”— How keenly I feel the truth of this, and of the whole passage relating to old age! and how deeply ought I to feel the exhortation— [“]Those shaking hands, weighed down by the burden of years—raise them towards Heaven. That voice, scarcely capable of articulating sounds, turn it up to God—implore of him that after having sustained you in the weakness of childhood, in the fire of youth in the dissipations of manhood, he would still support you in the decrepitude of the hoary head” And I do so pray to the father of all mankind.
3. IV:30. Monday

This morning one of the men, employed in digging Charles’s well, had his arm broken, by the falling of a stone, from those with which they were stoning it— He was at the bottom in search of a Pick axe, which they had left on Saturday, and which was stolen yesterday— They had dug fifty-five feet down. without coming to water and after going through a bed of clay many feet thick, had struck on a rock of flint— The well will therefore never have much water in it— There is in Quincy no Well-digger by profession— Charles was therefore obliged to engage one at Boston—a man named Higgins who sent out these workmen, but has scarcely been three hours here since the work began— It is hard work for the men, and this unfortunate accident indicates that it has not been carefully done— Dr Woodward set the mans arm, and he was taken this evening to Boston— One of the Stone-cutters named Chadwick, came and contracted for a granite ledge, nearly adjoining upon that now occupied by Colburn— Charles went over the hill with him to view the quarry, and returning found a woman with an axe, cutting down an Apple-tree to carry it away for fuel. She discussed the matter with him on the ground of moral principle; and pleaded the great scarcity of firewood as her apology for the liberties she was taking with her neighbour’s trees— After dinner, my wife, with Mary and Mrs Charles, went over to Hingham and visited Mrs Edward Thaxter— The day was uncommonly fine, and I walked to the Middle and the Druid Pasture— Stop’d and enquired for Deacon Josiah Adams, but he was gone upon his weekly pilgrimage to Boston. I went over the Druid pastures, and found very few acorns— Never indeed so few. The two old White Oaks, which I remember from my earliest childhood, and which seem to me no larger than when I first saw them, appear as flourishing as ever. On one of them there are a few acorns not yet ripe.
Returning home, I came by B. L. Crane’s lot which he purchased of me, and found it surrounded with a fence, and covered with blocks of stone, for his cellar— His father was buried this afternoon from his house— Home about Sunset— Whist part of the Evening— Planted half a fourth row in South front of Nursery fence; with Pear Seeds and Acorns, Peach and Plum stones—and miscellaneous seed in the Seminary front row.
4 V. Tuesday—

Charles went to Boston and returned to dine. Deacon William Spear came, and I went with him into the woods to inspect a lot, where he proposes to sell some of the standing wood. He found the bounds which we followed till we reached the line between Quincy and Milton where a red cross was marked upon one of the Stones of the heap which divides the two Towns— We turned off the road at the right hand a few rods beyond the corner of my lot purchased of James Baxter, and we proceeded about a mile before we came to the bounds of my lot which struck off obliquely from the Cart way over which we had walked—turning to the left hand westward— I recognized the site, and particularly the position of the rocks, but without being able to determine which of my lots it was— In going to it, we left at the right hand, a stupendous ledge of highpeaked granite rocks; partly in land lately purchased by Mr Leeds of James Baxter for 100 dollars an acre, and partly in mine— We returned shortly before noon, discouraged from staying longer out, by a northeasterly storm, which was threatening the whole day; but without much rain. It confined me however to the house for the remainder of the day— I received from Mr Eastburn, the first proof half sheet of the Eulogy on Madison which I corrected and sent back to him by the mail I made an attempt also to answer two or three Letters, but immediately found impediments and obstacles—particularly for the answer to John Farmer upon genealogies— I went to the Library and took out Willard’s Body of Divinity, to consult and take a copy of my father’s minute made on the blank leaf August 7. 1773. in which there are one or two errors of fact. Mr E. Price Greenleaf was here this Evening and brought me a bag full of Apples from natural trees, for seed—
5. V:15. Wednesday.

The storm continued through the night, and continued with heavy rain, and a Northeastern gale all this morning— The confinement to the house diverted my attention from my plantations, seedling trees and seeds, and turned it to my correspondence which is in confusion and in arrears— I copied into one of my Letter Books the entry in my father’s hand-writing upon the first blank leaf of Willards body of Divinity relating to the founder of our family in this Country Henry Adams— I looked also into Savage’s edition of Winthrop’s Journal, and examined the list of persons admitted as freemen, from October 1630 to May 1648. published in his appendix. I found of our name and apparently of our family William Adams 22. May 1639. Thomas and Samuel Adams 10. May 1643. but neither Henry, nor any of his other Sons.— But there are Jeremy Adams 6. May 1635. Richard Adams 2. September 1635. Ferdinando Adams 13 May 1640. Nathaniel Adams 26. May 1647. and Alexander Adams 10 May 1648— Here are five persons of the name not one of whom appears to have
been of the family of Henry Adams— It appears by the Braintree Town Records that Nathaniel Adams belonged to Weymouth, and in the earliest military organization of Braintree Henry, Thomas and Peter Adams are named as Sergeants and John and Joseph Adams as drummers— The order of the Sons of the first Henry Adams I believe was, Henry, Thomas, Samuel, Jonathan, Peter, John, Joseph and Edward— These genealogical enquiries where so little is to be known lead into a labyrinth— Once engaged in them time is lost for more useful purposes— I wrote to Mr Frye at Washington, and to William Lee at Roxbury—and sent him back the Newspapers that he had lent me— And I draughted the written agreement with Harvey Field, for the wood on the Atherton and Verchild Pastures, and for clearing five Acres of the Land—
6. V:30. Thursday.

Charles went into Boston, and returned to dine— And so did his mother with Mary, and Elizabeth C. Adams. William Spear came, and I went with him to the Atherton and Verchild Pastures after calling upon Mr Harvey Field who met us there. He has already begun cutting down the wood and is said to have made a very profitable bargain with me— We measured off a parcel of the lot, containing about five Acres, and Mr Field discussed the manner in which he was to clear them for one hundred dollars— He said much about selling the Stone, and building a good wall of which he had not spoken before; and concerning which I gave him no definitive answer— He shewed us a small patch through which he had run the plough this morning and of which the soil was very good; and on returning to his house we executed the agreement which I had drawn up, and which was witnessed by Mr Spear— I promised to send Mr Field a counterpart executed by me— I gathered apples from four several wilding trees for seed. After I came home Mr Frederick Soper was here to ask my advice concerning his claim as Master of a Vessel, belonging to Mr John Parker, which was taken at the time of the French depredations, and for which Mr Parker has now recovered indemnity, by the last Convention with France— He said he had applied to Mr Parker for his wages, until his return to the United States. That Mr Parker informed him that he had received his indemnity, from the French Government, but referred him for his claim to his Son in Law Mr Shimmin, who would do nothing.— I told him I thought he must apply to a lawyer to sue Mr Parker, and I thought he had a valid claim for his wages till he returned home. He said he would follow my advice— Dudley was here also wishing to make some arrangement for more land at the Quarry— I involved myself again in genealogical enquiries which consumed much of the day— Received the second half-sheet of proof which I revised and sent back to him—
7. V:30 Friday

Dudley was here again this morning, and made his arrangements with my Son Charles to whom he made return of the Stone that he has gotten out and carried away for some time past. Colburn and Dutton returned also 33 loads for the last fortnight, for the ledge worked by him in company with Colburn— I received from Eastburn, and revised the third half sheet of the Eulogy upon James Madison— In the afternoon I walked over the hill to the quarries recently opened upon my land. Hardwick has taken decisively, to the giant rock, and has split off from it several

very large blocks— I found Charles there, and we walked round where Dutton was at work upon his and Colburn’s ledge— We went also over that where Dutton himself is about to begin, and to the ground for which Chadwick has contracted— There are thus four different companies engaged upon Quarries, on a lot where one year since, I had not a suspicion that a quarry existed. I examined further the Apple trees and brought home, a pocket full of apples which I call farm purple spotted crab— The apple is of the yellow whitish colour, with scattered purpleish spots over it.— We held a party of our Quincy neighbours and acquaintance, at tea, and to a light supper of fruits, Ice-creams, jellies and champagne. Mr. Daniel Greenleaf told me that he expected to hear to-morrow morning of the death of his Sister Mrs. Bell, at New Bedford aged 85. That she was the second of nine brothers and Sisters who were all living last winter; and with the exception of Mrs Cranch were all over 70 years of age— Their average age was 74. which was his own age; his birthday being the 29th. of September 1762— Mr and Mrs Thomas Greenleaf were not here; he being much indisposed— Nor were any of Mr John Greenleaf’s family here— We had several card parties— I played with Mrs Miller, Mrs T. B. Adams and Mrs Edward Miller— The company left us about half past ten O’Clock— I remained till past 11. to see the fires well covered and the house closed.
8. V. Saturday

E. Price Greenleaf came between five and six O’Clock this morning, and I walked with him to the Bent’s point Bridge, where we viewed the extensive stone wharf now in the process of being built, which is a great and expensive work— Returning we stop’d at Mr Lemuel Brackett’s, and he took my acknowledgment of the Execution of the two deeds from the Executors of Ward N. Boylston, one of exchange to Mr Breed of Charlestown, and the other of a small portion of the lands at Princetown. Charles took them with him to Boston, where he and his wife went, and returned to dine— Alpheus Spear came to settle with me for a half year of his rent, but he had made up an account against me nearly absorbing it all, to a large part of which I objected, and after some discussion with me, he said he would come again this Evening, and pay me the rent deducting only the charges which I was willing to allow, and leave the rest to be settled hereafter; but he did not come— I transplanted 20 seedling Pear trees from the boxes at the West end of the Garden to a row in the Bartlett Pear tree bed between two willow stakes, and four double Peach Seedlings from one part to another of the same bed— I also trimmed several hickory trees in the Nursery and in the Garden, and planted in the Seminary a cross row of Greenleaf white Apple seeds with Crack wilding pear seeds—Peach and Plum [symbols] and [symbols] My design of tracing the varieties of fruits and of their trees to their respective seeds would require at least 30 years of constant experiments to its full execution— I have ascertained that the red, black, white, Chesnut and willow Oaks invariably produce their kinds from the Acorn— That the shag bark, white walnut and pignut do the same— Upon the Peach, I have neglected to make the same experiments, and
cannot trace the tree to the Stone— I see by my seedling Apple and Pear trees that there are great varieties especially in the rapidity and slowness of growth, and in the form and colour of the leaf, and I would trace them to the maturity of the tree and the quality of the fruit, and also back to the seed— But I have not the time— Half a century of annual experiments might be necessary for the developement of all the useful results— I urged Price Greenleaf this morning to repeat and continue the same experiments, and may possibly succeed in bringing him to it— He has time enough before him— This afternoon I walked round Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s grounds, but gathered only one Street crab apple and a few Tupelo berries— Closed the Evening between 8 and 9.
9. IV:45 Sunday—

Heard Mr Young, Minister of the New-South Meeting House at Boston, who preached in the morning, from Ecclesiastes 7:10. “Say not thou, What is the cause that the former days were better than these? for thou dost not inquire wisely concerning this”— A learned and interesting discourse— The preacher adhered closely to his text.— He did not deny that the former times were better than the present— The text itself appears to admit the fact with reference to the time, when it was written— The Book of Ecclesiastes is shewn from internal evidence, to have been composed by Solomon in his old age— The former days of his Life had certainly been better, both for his People and for himself than those of his last years, and it might be very desirable to him that his subjects should not enquire into the cause of this deterioration.— It is not to be denied that there are times better than others, and of course that the former days are sometimes better and sometimes worse than these— The text of Solomon applied therefore to his own former and latter days and can certainly not apply to these days in comparison with those of his age— Perhaps his meaning however was only to check the general propensity of old men to think the days of their youth better than those of their old age, and if so to be understood the precept of the text is instructive to all the generations of men, and guards against one of the besetting Sins of human nature— So the text was considered by Mr Young, and he argued against the folly of enquiring why the former days were better than these, by an historical review, to prove that it was not always so— He shewed also by analysing some of the times reputed to be the best, that they were times of great calamity and distress— Mr Young dined with us, and I found him of pleasant and instructive conversation— His Sermon after dinner was from Matthew 12.36. [“]But I say unto you, that every idle word, that men shall speak, they shall give account thereof in the day of judgment.” This has an appearance of harshness, but it must be received with two qualifications—first that by idle words are meant only words of irreverence to God or injurious to our neighbour— And secondly that we are to account to a merciful God, who will forgive or excuse trivial and unintentional offences. It is one of those rigorous precepts of Christianity in which the language of hyperbole is used to impress the mind with an important duty, which the untutored heart is prone to neglect or to disregard. It is a precept at once of prudence and of Justice— Inconsiderate speech is an infirmity incident to that faculty possessed only by man of all the animal creation, and as speech is the vehicle of thought, the instruction to curb the exercise of the faculty, is in its result a wise and benevolent regulation of the
heart. I read the fourth Sermon of the 9th. volume of Saurin, upon the vanity of the means of resistance against God—an excellent discourse, and peculiarly appropriate to the Christian Religion which lays the foundation of all morality in the will of God.— Thence it follows that all crime and all vice is resistance against the Will of God, and to teach men that all resistance against the will of God is vain is to teach them the practice of virtue.
10 IV. Monday

Mr Price Greenleaf came between five and six O’Clock this morning, and I walked with him to the Penn’s Hill, Atherton, and Verchild lot, where Harvey Field is cleaning up the land— We went also through the grove behind Henry Hardwick’s house, and came round by Mr Edward Miller’s house and through his grounds— After Breakfast Mr William Spear came and I went with him and my Son Charles, Mr Humphrey the Surveyor and Peter Turner to the six hundred Acres woods, and starting from Owens Field surveyed the lot which I have agreed to purchase of Peter Turner, adjoining upon my double lot, bordering on Owen’s Field. The lot is about 90 rods East and West and from 12 to 17. Rods wide— It is tangled with young growing wood, chiefly Oak and walnut; steep in ascent and descent, and fangled with briars and brambles— It was half past two in the afternoon when the survey was finished, and Peter Turner was very desirous of going immediately to survey another lot on Pine Hill; but I declined going and he gave it up.— While I was out, Thomas Vinson, an old claimant for an increase of Pension for services in the Revolutionary War was here, and left a paper in support of his claim.— We all except Mrs Adams went to an evening party and supper at Mr Edward Miller’s where together with the company of our late party we found also Mrs De Wint of Fishkill landing, and Mrs John Angier of Medford— I walked with Charles and Mr Price Greenleaf to Mr Miller’s— Whist with Mrs T. B. Adams, Mrs DeWint, andI invited Mrs De Wint to dine with us to morrow, which she promised, and Charles and I rode home with the Ladies— The party broke up about 11.
11. V.15. Tuesday.

Alpheus Spear came this morning, with Josiah Adams junr. and settled with me for his rent. Mr Adams agreed that the charge for digging and stoning the cellar of the new house at Mount Wollaston should not be placed in his account— I allowed it therefore to be deducted from Spear’s account for rent—and I further allowed 50 dollars for the drain; so that I deducted from Spear’s charges against me, only 37:50 for fencing, which he made without asking my consent, and he paid me the balance— Of my plantations, I transplanted a seedling Apple-tree about one inch high from Pot 14. to the first row in the Bartlett Pear-tree bed in the Garden— Then filled the Pot with fresh earth; and planted in it Seeds of the Farmpurple spotted faun-coloured Crab Apple; with wilding Pear seeds, old cherry stones, and some other things— Planted further a cross row in the Seminary a cross row of Penn’s Hill Carnation crab apple seeds, with wilding Pear-seeds 2. Tupelo berries, Peach, Plum and Cherrystones, and 1. Black walnut in the drupe; from Mr Miller’s.
Mrs De Wint, and Mrs Angier dined with us and Mary and Mrs Charles went with them to tea at Mrs T. B. Adams’s. Charles had been this morning to Boston and returned to dine— I walked with him this Evening to Mrs T. B. Adams’s, where were Mrs Edward Miller, and her daughter Hannah— Whist with Mrs Miller Louisa C. Smith and Mrs Charles—we rode home, the weather threatening a storm—
12. V. Wednesday.

Autumnal East and North-east storm, with a violent gale, and driving rain, which I found pattering against my windows when I first rose, and which continued without abatement till the afternoon. Two of our family were taken suddenly and severely sick— Mrs Wilson who Dr Woodward says, has a bilious fever, and Graymes the mulatto man, who has the Sciatica— I finished a Letter to Governor Edward Everett which I have been three days writing, but left my diary unfinished— I made a plan of the Land upon which my houses in Tremont Street, Boston are situated and found its area to be 8866 feet— Charles made it something more— It is a Trapezium of which the North-side on Boylston Street, called in John Lowell’s Deed to me Frog lane is 77 feet and half an inch—the South side 80 feet. The west side fronting on Tremont Street called in my Deeds Nassau-Street 109 feetinches, and the East side on Lowell Court 119 feetinches— I took the measure of the lines from Gunter’s scale of equal parts—then drew a diagonal line upon the plan—dropped two perpendiculars upon it, and multiplied the diagonal by the sum of the two perpendiculars: which gave the result of exactly double the square feet of the area. The measurements of the Deed from I. P. Davis are in round numbers, a parallelogram of 50 by 80 feet, more or less; but those in the Deed from Lowell, are precise to half an inch.— Just before Sunset the rain held up and I walked round my Seminary and Garden— We wasted the Evening at whist.
13. V:30. Thursday—

Peter Turner came this morning and asked me to go with him to survey his woodlot of 6 Acres on Pine hill adjoining the lot which I purchased in 1802 of James Baxter— But I told him I could not purchase it at present, and it would be of no use for me to attend the survey.— The price he asks is 500 dollars for the six acres. William Spear came, and Charles went with him to the Rail-way Quarries— I called at the Bank, at Elisha Turner’s— At the Post-Office, and upon Benjamin Bass, for the Policy of Insurance upon his house mortgaged to me, and which has been renewed for seven years from the first of August last. He had assigned the former policy to me— As it had expired I gave it to him to have it renewed— I asked him for the new Policy, when he paid me the interest on his note—he said it was in the hands of Lemuel Brackett the agent of the Insurance Company; and I might call for it upon him— I did call on him accordingly, but he said Bass had taken it away himself, refusing to execute an assignment of it, because there would be a charge of 50 cents for recording the Assignment on the company’s Books— Bass now said they would charge him a dollar for recording the Assignment, and he seemed disinclined to execute it— Said that a dollar was a dollar—that he had increased the sum insured upon his house, and that when I lent him the money, I had not asked for the assignment of his policy, but he had made it of his own accord— I said my recollections did not exactly agree with his, but it was true that the assignment of the policy had been his own offer, when he borrowed the money— That as to the increase of the Sum in the present policy, and the charge for recording the assignment, they were for his consideration, and if he preferred taking up his note, it would be more agreeable to me. He said that would not be convenient to him
at this time, and I said I would not press him for immediate payment But I would take the Policy to Mr Brackett, and ask him to make the Assignment upon it, which I should expect him to execute— He had given me the Policy and I took it with me. I came over the quarry hill, and visited the ledges— I examined also most of the fruit trees, on the several lots— I found several shagbark trees in bearing for the first time, and several new wilding Apple trees, under which I gathered a few apples for seed— I have found on the farm eight varieties of wilding Apples, and I propose to plant seeds of each of them separately, to observe which of them come up, and the comparative rapidity of their growth— For this I must rely upon my Pots and my Garden boxes— After dinner I transplanted 20 Seedling Apple trees from Garden box 1. to Bartlett Pear tree bed. Also six of seven Ash trees growing together between the Summer house cellar and the road. Four Seedling peach trees which I removed from near the tall Apple seedling of 1834. and two of three apple seedlings too near each other, Planted also in the Seminary, a cross row of nursery Pippin seeds, superannuated remnant of the golden pippin— My wife was taken very suddenly ill this Evening while at tea—and took immediately to her bed.
14. IV:45. Friday.

Mrs Adams had a quiet night but was very ill the whole of this day, though better in the Evening— Mrs Wilson and Graymes are still confined to their beds— Peter Turner was here twice— Early this morning when he brought me Mr Humphrey’s plan of his late Survey of the Owen’s Field wood lot, with his copy of the Survey by Mather Withington of the Savile and Will lots in 1829— In the Evening he brought me the evidence of his own title, which was a Quit-claim from his brothers and Sisters to him— Of their title he had no evidence—but he said it was part of his grandfather Peter Boylston Adams’s Estate, which after his death was set off to Mrs Turner his mother, and after her death descended to her children— He is to look up these Evidences.— His wife at first had executed the deed, renouncing her dower, but had not joined in the acknowledgement, which she afterwards did.— Mr William Spear came and I went with him to the Mount Wollaston farm, and examined the woods to fix upon a number of trees to be cut down, for fuel at my own house— The wood is almost entirely Oak and walnut, and I gathered a small number of black Oak acorns and white walnuts in the drupe, not yet ripe— All the acorns also float in water— On the way to Mount Wollaston, I stop’d at Mr Lemuel Bracketts, and left Benjamin Bass’s policy, for the assignment to be written upon it— And I desired Mr Brackett if Bass should refuse to execute the assignment, he would return the policy to me, which he promised to do. Thomas Adams junr was with him, and they had the plan of their House lots along by the Canal, before them— Returning from Mount Wollaston, I stoppd and looked over the house, which Josiah Adams junr. is just now about to finish, according to his contract with me— He says he will be ready for the painter next Monday— We had a morning visit from Mr and Mrs Barrell, from Boston—and after dinner, Bryan Johnson, second Son of Alexander B. Johnson of Utica, New-York, was here— He brought me a Letter of introduction from his father. He is a youth of 18 or 19. and has been two or three years in the counting house of Edwin Lord, and Co. importers of dry goods in the City of New York. He arrived this morning from New-York, he said on business, and that he must leave Boston to-morrow Morning to return— His mother was the second daughter of my
brother Charles; an excellent woman, who died about two Months since; an irreparable loss to her family— There was an evening party and supper at our next door neighbour’s Mr Beale’s, at which we attended; and where we met the usual Quincy company: with the addition of Mercy and Susan Tufts from Weymouth— Whist before supper with Mrs T. B. Adams, Charles’s wife and Dr Woodward and after supper with Mr and Mrs Thomas Greenleaf and Mrs Edward Miller— We came home before 11. O’Clock.
15. V:15. Saturday

I slept in my writing chamber. Mrs Adams was much better, but kept her bed the whole day. Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— Peter Turner was here again, and brought the copies of Records from the probate Office, assigning the woodlot, bounded upon Owens Field to Mary Turner Peter’s mother, and the inventory upon the administration on her Estate by his brother Elisha, upon which the same lot is noted. He said the reason of his fixing a stake at the head of the lot which he sells was because by my plan of my father’s Savile lot taken by Withington, one half of the width of his lot was taken away. I still wished to see the Deeds to my uncle Peter Boylston Adams, and that Josiah Bass junr. whose land borders on the lot now sold by Peter Turner should explicitly assent to the boundary stake set up by Peter Turner. He said he had sold the adjoining lot of ten Acres to Josiah Bass junr, who had lately asked him to go, and shew him the bounds. He would therefore obtain Bass’s assent to the bounds of the lot now surveyed by Mr Humphrey and which I have agreed to purchase— I was great part of the morning on the garden, and trimmed one of the willow trees which have grown from Stakes set out by me in 1832 also two Hickories and one red Oak, the ruts and acorn of which were planted by me in 1831. and which are now about 8 feet high. From this I infer the average growth of those trees; the red Oak and the pignut hickory, for five years—about 19 inches a year; but in this case as in that of the tall apple seedling the growth of the second year is equal to that of any two other years— The black and white Oaks and the Shagbark Hickory are of much slower growth; but of healthy plants, in a suitable soil, I believe the second years growth surpasses all others— I planted in Pot 20. Seeds of the farm double-stock apple and 20. of the Brown sugar pear. After dinner and towards Sunset I walked over to Charles’s lot which he is laying out, where his cellar is partly stoned, and his well has 16 feet deep of water. Thence I went to the Coburn and Dutton ledge, where the workmen were just ceasing from their labour, and whence after the setting of the Sun I returned— In the Evening I attempted to read a Chapter of Benjamin Constant upon religion but without success.
16. V.15. Sunday

Heard Mr Walker of Charlestown, this morning from Matthew 6.13. “and lead us not into temptation”—and in the afternoon from 2. Corinthians 5.4 [“]For we that are in this tabernacle do groan, being burdened: not for that we would be unclothed, but clothed upon, that mortality might be swallowed up of life.” The discourse of the morning was upon temptation—that of the afternoon upon [“]Life, Death and immortality.” There is some obscurity in the text of the afternoon, but both the discourses were admirable. That upon Temptation especially was an impressive treatise of rigorous morality— The explanation of the true meaning of the text discarded the difficulty of the construction too commonly given to it, and which supposes that the Deity should ever lead men into temptation. He said that the excusatory plea of temptation was a subterfuge, and that in nine cases of ten the temptation was sought by the sinner himself.— The Sermon upon death was in many passages pathetic—and the argument that the dead are not dead
either to themselves, or to their relatives and friends or their Country was the same with that of Socrates in the Phaedo.— Mr Walker dined with us, and Mr Degrand who came out from Boston.— I had only the Evening left for reading the 5th. Sermon of the 9th. Volume of Saurin, upon true Heroism—from Proverbs 16.32. He that ruleth his Spirit, is better than he that taketh cities— Saurin has it, he who is master of his own heart; and he comments upon the expression of the original Hebrew, which signifies the breath— He supposes that the text will be taken by critics for extravagant exaggeration, and admits that there is in the Scriptures much oriental hyperbolical imagery: but he insists that in this case, there is no exaggeration, and that the text is literally true— I believe it so— The taking of Cities is seldom an atchievement of good men; and to say that the master of his own Passions is a better man than a conqueror, is to give him but feeble praise.— The Sermon is very good, but did not quite equal my expectations from the text— I read also a Chapter of Benjamin Constant’s work upon Religion.
17. IV:45 Monday

Thermometer 34. Charles went to Boston and returned to dine. Mr Johnson from the rail-way Quarry was here. The company have concluded to make no further purchases, and will leave to an arbitration the damages due to me for the land they have taken from me by running their railway through my lots in three several places— Mr Augustus Story, a nephew of Judge Story of the Supreme Court of the United States, brought me a Letter of recommendation from Stephen C. Phillips, of Salem— Mr Story is a young man; a graduate of Harvard University; and has just completed a course of legal study, at the Law School at Cambridge, and is going to Michigan, with the purpose of making a settlement there— Mr Phillips recommends him to me for introductory Letters— He proposes to go from Boston the day after to-morrow— I gave him a Letter for Lucius Lyon, who was the delegate from the Territory of Michigan in the last Congress, and a Senator-elect from the State at the present Congress; and I took the occasion of writing a short answer to two Letters which I have recently received from Mr Lyon, concerning the rejection by the Convention of the People of Michigan of the Condition upon which by the Act of Congress of 15 June last the State was admitted into the Union. Mr Lyon urges me to write out and publish the Speech which I made at the second reading of the Bill; of which no report whatever has appeared in the Newspapers— Mrs T. B. Adams was here this morning, and her daughter Elizabeth after dinner— She, with my two daughters and Charles spent the Evening at Mr Beale’s with the family of Edward Miller, who remove to-morrow for the winter to Boston— Mrs Adams is recovering, and sat up the greater part of this day, but did not leave her chamber— The mornings are now so cold that I find it impossible to write before breakfast; and there are so many objections to my walks, that I take to reading; and have engaged with Benjamin Constant’s work upon Religion— A large work, founded upon a first principle that man is by nature a religious animal— That he cannot but by a denial of his nature be otherwise, and that all the different religions which have prevailed upon earth are only diversified modifications of this one universal and inextinguishable property of human nature— This is not an original idea, but the view in which he presents it and the consequences which he deduces from it are important. I planted a row of Apple and Pear seeds—Peach, Plum and Cherry Stones in front of the Nursery fence—a Cross row of Central Nursery Crab-Apple seeds with Pear, Peach—Plum and Cherry seeds and Stones in Seminary—and Siberian Crab and Pear-seeds in Pot 12—
18. IV:30. Tuesday. Fahrenheit 30.

Reading Benjamin Constant upon Religion— The work is philosophical, and considers all religions as, only different modifications of one universal inward, but not innate Sentiment of the human heart. He also disclaims all intention to contest the truth of the Christian religion according to the Protestant forms, but his reasoning is, not easily reconcileable with the admission of a special revelation—either in the new or in the old Testament— I was called in from the garden, to Peter Turner and Josiah Bass junr. about the woodlot which we lately surveyed, and which I have agreed to purchase— I shewed Mr Bass the plan made out by Mr Humphrey, and stated that as Mr Turner had set up a Stake for a new Corner bound between him, Bass and me, I thought it necessary to have his written assent to the bound to avoid all controversy hereafter— Bass said he was willing to give his written assent to a corner bound, but he should wish first to see it— And Peter Turner agreed to go with him some day this or the next week and view the whole ground— A Mr Fuller from Philadelphia, brought the first number of Coll. M’Kenney’s, magnificent work upon the Indian Tribes—a large Folio pamphlet, with six coloured lithographic Portraits of Indians— There are to be nineteen more such numbers; to constitute a Volume—at six dollars a number—for which Mr Fuller solicited my Subscription. I declined it as being costly beyond my means. He said, if I would subscribe my name, I should receive the numbers without cost, as I had myself contributed to the composition of the work. I also declined to receive it upon those terms.— In the garden, I planted a row, the fourth between the Summer house cellar and the road, with 30 whole Office Apples, Sundry Pear Cores—Peach, Plum and Cherry Stones, Tupelo Berries, and a Black walnut in the drupe— After dinner I strolled over the hill; saw the Stone-cutters at work and gathered some Farm Apples and Shagbark walnuts— I called a the house of Benjamin Bass, but he was gone to Boston— In the Evening we had whist in my wife’s chamber.
19. V. Wednesday— Fahrenheit 36.

Charles went into Boston, and returned to dine— William Spear came, and I went with him over the Hill and shewed him three Apple-trees, the old Trunks of which have been torn and split down, and left on the ground to be taken away at a convenient time for fuel— The lot was formerly an Orchard— The Apple trees are large, and have had upon them many heavy boughs and branches fit for fire wood— These Trespassers have followed the business of cutting and carrying them away as an occupation— All the large and decayed limbs have been lopped off heretofore; and now they split down and hack off the body of the tree— We found in the hollow of one of the trees an old evacuated bee-hive, and a large mass of decayed honey comb— I engaged Mr Spear to have the trees all brought over to my own yard where use for them for fuel will be found in our own house—we went round by the Quarries, and found Dutton, and three other men at work upon one of them, and three of Hardwick’s men upon another— And there was one man, stripping off the soil from the rock upon which Dutton proposes to begin— I parted from Spear, and called upon Benjamin Bass, to hasten him for the execution of the assignment upon his Policy, Mr Brackett had sent me word that he had notified Bass that the Assignment was ready for execution by him; but that he had not done it— Bass shuffled and equivocated—said he would do it, but that it was no part of his bargain— I was very indignant at his tergiversations, and told him
I was much surprized at his attempt to withdraw the security, he had given me, upon the renewal of his policy, and that if he did not execute the assignment, I would put the mortgage into the hands of a lawyer to be sued. Upon this he waxed valiant; said he was a republican, and was not to be frightened, and I might put the mortgage in suit this very day, if I wanted to put him to the cost of a few dollars— That perhaps he would get the money and take up his Note— I told him I should take it as a favour if he would, for that from his conduct now, I wished to have as few dealings with him hereafter as possible.— He said my character was known throughout the Nation—and that he was not to be frightened— Not into honesty? said I—he said he was an honest man, and never wronged any man to the value of a cent—and that I had better put his mortgage in suit this very day.— I determined to have no further altercation with him; and left him— He is not absolutely a dishonest, but a trickish man; and as he is wrong in this case he will ultimately come to his sense of duty by his own reflections.— Returning home, I gathered some farm bitter sweeting Apples, Button Pears, and Split rock Shag barks— I made out a Deed to my Son Charles of the land for his house lot; and wrote over again the Deed of Saltmarsh land to Henry Hardwick which was executed the first of this month but not acknowledged— I found on reading it over, that there was a considerable omission in the description of the boundary— I went to Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s, and he at my request came to my house, and witnessed with Mary, and took the acknowledgments of my wife and of me, to the two Deeds; one of which I forthwith delivered to my Son— I asked Mr Greenleaf to say to his Son, that if he would call on me to-morrow morning, I would walk with him— Mr Johnson from the Rail-road was here to see my Son, but was disappointed; and Peter Turner came this Evening with a note addressed to me, signed by Josiah Bass junr and declaring his consent to the establishment of a permanent boundary, at the place where Turner set up the Stake.— I then said there was now nothing to be done, but to establish the boundary there, and I agreed to go with him Saturday morning for that purpose— He engaged to give notice to Mr Bass, that he may attend if he thinks fit, and to William Spear—
20. IV. Thursday.

E. Price Greenleaf came this morning about six O’Clock, and we walked to Penn’s Hill— I called upon Henry Hardwick and I gave him the Deed executed and acknowledged, of the strip of Saltmarsh land, which he purchased of me— I went and viewed the land upon the Verchild Pasture which Harvey Field has engaged to clear up; and upon which he has cut down the trees.— Passed through the Oak and walnut grove in the rear of Hardwick’s House, and found a very few black, and white Oak Acorns— Mr. Johnson from the Railway was here and Charles went with him to the Quarry— The company now chuse to take a lease of the land which they want belonging to me, and Charles has agreed to give them one for ten years.— I transplanted an Apple seedling from Pot 8 to the first row in the Bartlett Pear bed, and planted the Pot Farm Rosebud Apple seeds and St. Michael Pear seeds—with Cherry stones.
Trimmed a number of growing Apple seedlings, and Elms and two honey locusts. Charles took up an elm towards the North end of my Nursery, which he set out there in 1829. and which is fifteen feet high— Mr Benjamin V. French and Mr Harvey Field, called upon me this Evening, as a Committee from an Antimasonic Meeting of Citizens of the 12th. Congressional District, with sundry Resolutions, respecting the approaching Election, for Electors of President and Vice-President, for Governor and Lieutenant Governor of the State, and for a member of the House of Representatives in Congress for the District— Several of the Resolutions have reference to me, and my conduct, and they nominate me for re-election not as a special party nomination, but with a declaration of their confidence in my judgement and integrity— I told them that I received with great satisfaction this renewed mark of confidence from the Anti-masons of the District— That conscious as I was of deserving no more credit than for the intention of doing my duty to my constituents, and how much they had overrated the value of my services, I could only say that if re-elected to Congress, I should continue to act on the same principles upon which I have served the People of the District, in three successive Congresses.— That with regard to the other elections, I deemed it only necessary to say that I should take no part in them, unless the election of President of the United States should devolve upon the House of Representatives— In which event my vote will be representative, and not individual, that is, if I can ascertain for whom a majority of my Constituents of the District shall have manifested a preference I shall vote for him; be he who he may.— Mr Field suggested that it might be desirable that my answer should be given in writing, to which Mr French assented, and I promised to send a written answer— Mr Jacob S. Carr, and Miss Catherine Ann Goods were married this Evening at my house, and in the presence of all my family, by the Revd. Mr Lunt. Carr is a brother of my tenant John J. Carr, who with his wife and two other brothers, and several other persons were present— The time for the wedding was fixed at seven O’Clock— Mr Lunt came late and the ceremony was performed about 8. O’Clock— Catherine Ann Goods is a daughter of Mrs Goods, the Nurse of Mary’s children at Washington— She came with us last Summer in the same capacity, and here formed the acquaintance with the young man, which has now resulted in their marriage— They have both good characters— May the blessing of God follow their union, and may they be blessings to each other! The bridal party had a jovial supper— I retired early to bed.
21. III:30. Friday

Walk with Mr E Price Greenleaf, round on the Neponset Bridge Turnpike, returning by the way of the Railway Meeting House and Mrs Baxter’s— There is a Granite Stone Post at the dividing line between Quincy and Milton, and where according to the antient perambulations there was formerly a sturdy Oak.— There are still two Black Oak trees on the side of the road and near where that was,— From one of those Oaks I gathered half a dozen Acorns; there were not many more upon the tree— I planted four of them this afternoon, with five white Oak Acorns gathered yesterday from the Hardwick grove, four Shag barks from the Garden tree—sundry Farm red wedge Apple seeds, St Michael Pear Cores, and cherry stones, under the western garden fence, between a seedling elm tree and the transplanted red maple— Elizabeth C. Adams was here yesterday at the wedding; slept here last Night, and went to Boston this morning with Mary, Charles and his wife— They returned home before dinner; but Mary was very sick, and took immediately to her bed. Dr Woodward was sent for and is apprehensive of a bilious fever— This discomposed again our domestic establishment and Mrs Kingsbury,
who has been eleven weeks, ostensibly serving as housemaid or washerwoman in the house, this day took her departure. William Spear was here, and promised to go with Peter Turner and me to-morrow morning, to set up the boundary at the Woodlot.
22. III:45. Saturday—

Fahrenheit 29.— William Spear came immediately after breakfast this morning— We took up Peter Turner and went to the six hundred Acres woodland: taking our departure from Owen’s Field we went to the Stake which Turner had set up on the 10th. instt when Mr Humphrey made the survey; and surrounded with an heap of heavy Stones the stake; and I took with my pocket compass the direction of the boundary line to the Northern Corner; which was N. & by West, less than half west and we went to the Northern bound 13. 1/2 rods across— Returning we looked at the 3 half Oak tree which is the corner of another of my woodland lots— We then came home and I gave Turner a check for 391. dollars 25 cents for the Deed of 7. Acres and 132 rods of Wood-land according to the Survey— He took the Deed with him to have a slight correction made by Mr Brackett who draughted it. Elizabeth C. Adams was here, and after dinner went with Mrs Charles and the children to visit Mrs Tufts at Weymouth— I strolled over the hill, and looked at Charles’s cellar and two rows of young Elms, which he is setting out on the Northwest side of his lot— I went also to the Quarries where Dutton and Hardwick are at work, one with six and the other with five men— Mr Beale was here this Evening and we passed it at whist— Mary was confined to her chamber— I have read through the first and second Books of Benjamin Constant upon Religion and approve much of his object, and of his manner of treating it with one exception. That almost half the work consists of Notes— I hold the opinion that a book intended for duration should never have any notes— Every Note is a digression— It destroys the unity which is the first law of all literary composition— The substance of every useful note should be woven into the body of the work itself— I do not object to a mere citation of authorities; but argumentative or illustrative matter should not be separated from the general thread of the discourse. A Book full of Notes is like a human body covered with excrescences
23. V. Sunday—

Fahrenheit 32. Heard Mr Lunt this morning from 1. Thessalonians 1.5. “For our gospel came not unto you in word only, but in power, and in the Holy Ghost, and in much assurance” and in the afternoon from John 1.46. “And Nathanael said unto him, can there any good thing come out of Nazareth? Philip saith unto him, come and see”— These discourses were less impressive than I have been accustomed to hear from Mr Lunt, but I had some compensation in hearing Watts’s admirable 100th. Psalm sung— I read the 6th. Sermon of the 9th Volume of Saurin, upon the Ways of God to Man, and the ways of Man to God— His text is that most remarkable passage of the prophet Ezekiel Chapter 18. v. 29–32 in which the ways of God to the house of Israel; and the ways of the People of Israel to God are contrasted with each other— It is one of those Sermons in which this author not unfrequently runs foul of difficulties of which he knows not how to dispose. He professes to discard all the controverted questions about Fate, free will and predestination; but he cannot altogether avoid them.— I read also with references to the passages relating to them in the book about half the Notes to the work of Benjamin Constant upon Religion— There are 240 of them to the first Volume— So that it is scarcely possible to read half
a page of the text without interruption— Price Greenleaf proposed to me to walk with him this Evening over to Dr Holbrook’s but I declined— I promised however to walk with him to-morrow Morning, if the weather should be fair. Louisa C. Smith was here after meeting this afternoon— Mary appears to be recovering, but was still confined the whole day to her chamber and much of the time to her bed—
24. III:45. Monday.

Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— A warm Summer day— Price Greenleaf came half an hour before Sunrise, and walked with me to Mount Wollaston and the Beach— I took with my pocket compass the bearings of the strip of Saltmarsh land, which I have sold to Henry Hardwick, and which in the Deed to him are given conjecturally and indefinitely— We found the first line of 8 rods and 8 links N.E. and by N— The second line of 5. Rods W.N.W— The third seven Rods S.W by W. and the fourth 9. S.E by E corresponding very exactly with the first plan I had drawn, and making a lot of 49 rods and 66 feet— I gathered a pocket full of white walnuts; the intermediate between the Shellbark and the pignut called by Dr Bigelow the white walnut, and by Michaux the Mockernut. I could find no good Acorns. We returned late to Breakfast— Harvey Field was here, and settled with Charles, for his rent— William Spear brought me Peter Turner’s deed, and the policy upon Benjamin Bass’s house, the Assignment of which he refused to execute— He demanded it of Mr Brackett as his property, and upon Bracketts declining to give it to him, was so insolent that Brackett ordered him out of his house— Mr Johnson from the Railway was here again, and Charles agreed with him for the execution of the lease to the Company. Louisa C. Smith dined with us— I planted in the plats, round two seedling Horse Chesnuts in the Seminary, the seeds of Farm purple spot and blushing crab apples with St. Michael Pear seeds and cores; and in each plat a shellbark bud in the drupe— Transplanted from Pot 10. four Apple seedlings to the front row of the Bartlett pear bed in the Garden, and 13. Seedling Apple trees and 1. Pear from Garden box 2 to the same bed— I trimmed 12 Seedling Pignut trees growing in one row, in the centre barren of the Nursery: they are in their third or fourth year and three of them are near five feet high— An unusual and remarkable fact of these trees is that of the twelve nuts planted in the row, every one has come up, and has lived to this time. It proves that the tree may be very easily raised— I this day finished reading the notes to the first volume of Benjamin Constant upon Religion. The first Book is introductory. The second treats of Religion, as its influence operates upon man in the savage State— Our evening was idle— I received this morning from Mr Eastburn, two half sheets of proof of the Eulogy on Madison— The missing one, from page 58 to 66. and the last from page 81 to 87, which finishes— I corrected the proof immediately and sent it back by the mail—
25. IV:15. Tuesday.

Yesterday was as warm as midsummer, and last Evening the weather continued as mild— On rising this morning I omitted going out of the house, or to examine the thermometer, and when Mr Price Greenleaf knocked at my door I was altogether unaware of the change which had happened in the state of the atmosphere— I went out unsuspicious of the Northwestern gale; but on ascending the hill from the bridge in the valley fronting Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s house met the blast of a Counsellor which feelingly persuaded me what I was— I hesitated till we had reached the declivity fronting Coll. Quincy’s gate, whether to turn back or proceed. We pushed on however, and completed our walk round the railway square, and as we returned looked at the two rising Granite houses which Flanders and Willard are building just
this side of the Rail-way church, in Milton— The wintry cold continued, though with a clear sky, and bright Sun, the whole day— The garden was very repulsive— I planted in pot 10. about 30 Farm red wedge Apple seeds and 20 Seeds of Farm wilding Pears— This red wedge Apple is a crab; but so peculiar in form and colour that I have an earnest curiosity to see what sort of a plant it will produce, and how it will grow— I gathered also a number of the Shell-bark walnuts, now just ripe, upon the tree in the garden, near the Summer house cellar, and after dinner I planted, at each of the four Corner’s of my Son Charles’s house lot 3 of these nuts. 1 central, in the drupe, and one on each side of it, about two inches distant from it, and all about 2 inches deep; the ground being just broken up by John Toohey— I planted 3 of these nuts at each corner with the hope that one of the three may come up and grow there—and I chose this day for the plantation, because it is the anniversary day of my father’s marriage in 1764. I began reading this morning, the second Volume of Benjamin Constant upon Religion— The Notes in this volume, still vexatiously numerous, are at the bottom of the pages—and therefore less troublesome than at the end of the Volume—
26. V— Wednesday— Fahrenheit 24.

A second January day in October— A clear sky, and brisk gale from the N.W. blowing the whole day— It did not wholly confine me to the house; but abridged my plantations; and very much curtailed my proposed experiments— I planted Farm Russet and Penn’s Hill red bullet Apple-seeds and St. Michael Pear seeds, with garden walnuts Peach Stone and Plum but with utter uncertainty whether any of them will come up, or grow— I now first observe the varieties of form, between my garden Shellbark; the farm Shellbark and the Mount Wollaston white Walnut or Mockernut— They are all perfectly distinguishable from one another, and I believe the varieties of the pignut might be noted with equal certainty. I have hitherto raised them promiscuously, and can as yet discern the different kinds of the trees only by the number of the leaflets on each stalk— I have seedlings growing certainly of the three kinds, and the growth of some of them of each kind, is rapid beyond expectation— That of others exceedingly slow.— Every year now gives occasion to new observations on the growth of seedling Oaks, Elms, Walnuts, Buttonwood, Ash, and Nettletree; as well as of Apple, Pear, cherry, Peach and Plum and I have now to add the Maple.— Mr P. Greenleaf brought me yesterday morning a large Winter Squash, which he has raised from the seed that we brought from Nantucket, and which he has very successfully cultivated— My Son Charles has taken up to set out on his place, many of my seedling Oaks and Elms, and with them, the Stake Button-wood which I planted in 1831. and which is now perhaps 12 feet high. It was too near a Shellbark tree planted as a nut from the garden walnut, also in 1831. and now about five feet high— This I wish to preserve and retain in its place, and have therefore removed from it all inconvenient neighbours.— My observations become confused as they multiply, and I now see the necessity of methodizing them—without yet discovering the method of making them ultimately useful.— I am reading the second Volume of Benjamin Constant’s work upon Religion— It consists of historical illustrations adduced in proof of the Theory set forth in the first Volume— Religion is an essential property of man— It is in substance the same in all ages and all Countries, but is perpetually diversified in its forms. The Savage worships a familiar Spirit— With the dawn of civilization appears the worship of the Sun moon and stars, which introduces immediately an order
an order of Priesthood; and thence forward religion resolves itself into the dominion of the Priesthood.
27. V:30. Thursday.

Fahrenheit 22— Third winter morning in succession— So cold that I could only read Benjamin Constant till breakfast time— Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— I had intended to go with him, but was deterred by the severity of the weather— The ground was so hard frozen—that it was in bad condition for receiving seeds— I planted however 3 garden shellbark nuts, sundry farm Rock Ruby Apple-seeds and farm Button Pear seeds, at the gate corner of the Seminary. There are now 2 Seedling walnut trees and 6 Apple seedlings there from nuts and seeds which I planted last Fall— As the chances are that the winter will kill most or all of these, I plant these all for the purpose of raising one corner tree; Apple or Pear or Walnut, alteri Seculo— Mrs Tufts, with her daughter Susan and Miss Brooks, and then Mrs Lunt visited our Ladies this afternoon, and Mr E. Price Greenleaf brought me some wild plums for seed— Towards evening I walked over to the Quarries where Dutton and Hardwick are at work, and gathered pignuts from several trees, to ascertain if possible their varieties—also a few red wedge crab apples for seed a fruit so peculiar in its shape, apparently so prolific and the seeds of which have so healthy an aspect that it has excited my curiosity to observe its powers of reproduction— I wrote little, but read Benjamin Constant upon Religion— His third book is upon the causes which favour the growth of the sacerdotal power in the first advances of man in the progress of civilization— The fourth book is upon the influence of secondary causes upon the extent of the sacerdotal power— The main position of the book is that the worship of the Stars and of the Elements, originates the sacerdotal power, which once introduced absorbs the religious principle and makes of it an instrument for its own aggrandizement— Mrs Adams was unwell this evening.
28. IV:15. Friday.—

Fahrenheit 20— Fourth successive Winter Morning— The temperature of January in October— In the course of the day however, the wind came round to the Southward and the weather moderated. The cold benumbs my fingers so that I cannot write before breakfast, and I have been over persuaded to intermit my morning walks— Reading is the only resource left me and I return to Benjamin Constant upon Religion— The plan of the work is obviously borrowed from that of Montesquieu’s Spirit of Laws, and its great object appears to be to receive or sustain the sentiment of Religion, by urging the exclusion of all priesthood. I read this morning the 10th. and 11th. chapters of the 4th. book, in which he makes the application of his system of opinions to the History of the Jews as recorded in the old Testament— He does not absolutely reject a divine revelation; but he sees in the Jewish History, as in that of other Nations the struggle between the Sacerdotal, and the Military power— He passes a high encomium upon the institutions of Moses, and severely censures Voltaire, and the philosophical detractors of the Jewish Nation in the 18th. century— He treats with profound contempt the ridiculous panegyrics of Voltaire upon the Chinese, and perhaps indulges excessive prejudices against that Nation— I passed the remainder of this day in strenuous idleness.— A man by the name of Hosea Hatch came to see me; for the sake of having to say that he had seen a man, who was once President of the United States— He said he was a native of New-Hampshire; but has resided several years in Vermont, and for the last few months has been living here in Quincy, and working as a Shoemaker. He is about returning to New Hampshire— He says that Mr Flanders one of the
principal quarry-men of this town is his nephew, and bears his name. He asked my opinions upon politics and public men; which I gave him; but he did not give his own; though he was very anxious to vote for Electors of President and Vice-President— He was strongly prejudiced against the Irish and earnest for the enactment of a Law to exclude them, from coming into the Country— He kept me in conversation nearly two hours, to the great detriment of my plantations— I planted one row of Garden walnuts with Apple seeds in front of the Nursery fence, and intended to have done much more— A fourth row of transplanted seedling fruit trees was set out in the Seminary—Peaches, Cherries and Black Walnuts— In taking up one of these we found a white worm, I believe the same that is called the Potato worm near three inches long and two in circumference, busily engaged in demolishing the root of the tree— I had it set out for the experiment, but without hope that it will survive— We had whist this Evening.
29. IV: Saturday—

Fahrenheit 32— There was frost again this morning— The weather continuing clear and warm in the middle of the day, and frosty again at night— Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine—the Ex-deacon Josiah Adams paid me a long morning visit. He complains of rhumatism: but is 73 years of age and his Constitution is breaking up— He wants to purchase a lot of standing wood near his house, and belonging to me— He says that Harvey Field cannot for 100 dollars clear one acre of my Verchild Pasture, to make it fit for Tillage— Mr Thomas Loring of Hingham, brought me an indenture of the Patentee Charles Lane; being a reconveyance to him of his Patent right for a fire grate, which he desired me to get recorded at the Patent Office in Washington— Mr John A. Green brought me a subscription paper to enable him to purchase a printing Press to commence the publication of his projected newspaper— I declined to subscribe.— The day slipped away again, and my plantations make little progress— I only put seven cross rows of Farm Apple-seeds in Garden box one, with a few wild plum stones, cherry stones, and lengthways two Garden, one white and one farm walnut— I have marked on slips of willow names of six varieties of the Apple-seeds— This Evening I received a Letter from Mr Armstrong the Mayor of Boston with 100 copies of the Eulogy on James Madison.
30. V. Sunday—

Fahrenheit 32.— Heard Mr Lunt this morning from Proverbs 4.7. [“]Wisdom is the principal thing: therefore get wisdom.” This was one of the most pleasing discourses that I have ever heard delivered by Mr Lunt— After explaining the various senses in which the term Wisdom is used in the Scriptures, he gave the definition of its meaning as employed in this passage of the Proverbs, by Solomon; as the regulating power of human conduct; consisting of Prudence, tempered with Piety and benevolence— He analysed this property, by comparing it with learning, with philosophy, and with knowledge, and shewing its superiority to them all— His doctrine was intelligible to all his hearers endowed with a common share of understanding, and were addressed to all classes of his people— His afternoon Sermon was from Galatians 3.24.—Wherefore the Law was our Schoolmaster, to bring us unto Christ, that we might be justified by faith and he gave an exposition of the principles upon which the Mosaic law was the Schoolmaster
introductory, and preparatory to the Christian dispensation— The subject was nearly identical, with that of the 7th Sermon of the 9th. Volume of Saurin, which I read, and the text of which was from Habakkuk 2.4. “The just shall live by his faith.” This passage of the prophet is cited and repeated by St Paul in several of his Epistles, and among the rest in this very chapter of the Epistle to the Galatians.— Saurin as if in spite of himself, and apparently against his will involves himself in the endless controversy concerning the comparative merits of faith and of good works— Mr Lunt ranged alongside of them, but without discussing them— His course is the wisest— Louisa C. Smith dined with us, and I was obliged to write, all the evening— Charles and his wife spent it on a visit to Mr and Mrs Lunt.
31. V: Monday.

Fahrenheit 30.— Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— I sent by him an answer to the Letter from the Mayor of the City, Samuel T. Armstrong, and a note to the City Printer Eastburn, asking him to return my manuscripts, and sending him a list of errata, in the printed Eulogy— The most material error is the date of Mr Madison’s decease, which is printed the 21st. instead of the 28th. of last June— John Hardwick was here, and I executed with him the lease of the quarry upon which he is working. Charles had prepared it to be executed to-morrow, but Hardwick said he was going out of town this afternoon, to be absent to-morrow, and he was anxious to have the lease executed now, which was accordingly done— Hardwick inclined to talk politics, and to know my opinions and my preferences between the Presidential Candidates— I told him I had no preference of my own, and that if I should have occasion to vote for either in the house, I should vote for him whom I should have reason to believe most acceptable to the majority of my Constituents— Elisha Turner sent his Son Peter here with his Bill— Mary and Charles’s wife took tea and spent the Evening at Mrs T. B. Adams’s. I wasted much of the day in assorting seeds of Apple and Pear trees to be planted so as to ascertain which of the different kinds will, and which will not come up— I planted in the Seminary four cross rows of different Apple and Pear seeds, with wild plum stones, and Garden, farm, and white walnuts— The seedlings from the boxes are all transplanted into the Bartlett Pear tree bed.

Day— I still rise between four and six O’Clock, and have usually about an hour’s occupation, in making my fire for which I have most of the time to bring the wood from the yard to my chamber, and not seldom also to saw the wood— This is my substitute for the exercise of walking five or six miles before breakfast with Mr Price Greenleaf a practice which I have believed salubrious, but which Dr Bigelow, Dr Waterhouse, and Dr Huntt, by suggestions I suppose from my own family have dogmatically interdicted, and which I have therefore almost given up— I have however walked on several mornings with Price Greenleaf, and think I have endured the cold more easily for it— I hear my two Grand daughters children of my ever lamented son John read every morning in the Bible— The eldest Mary Louisa has read through the Old Testament, and now reads with her Sister daily two chapters of the new Testament, and alone, one of the Apocrypha— I have for the last fortnight also read every morning several chapters of Benjamin Constant on Religion. From breakfast to dinner my time is absorbed by a variety of domestic concerns, and again after dinner till dark now a very short interval— In the Evening I can neither read nor write with comfort, by the failure of my eye sight of which I am daily made more and more sensible— My Diary is therefore insensibly running into arrears, and my correspondence much more so— My purposes of plantation, I must as usual leave almost wholly unaccomplished.
